feedback.Physical object: Excluded — A diagram is not inherently a physical object, though it can be instantiated as one.
feedback.Man-made / synthetic: Included — It is a human-created conceptual and visual tool.
feedback.Biological or biologically-inspired: Excluded — It has no biological basis.
feedback.Fixed/static: Excluded — As a concept, it is not physically immobile or fixed in form.
feedback.Structural: Excluded — It has no material or physical structure.
feedback.Perceptible: Included — It is inherently visual; designed to be seen and interpreted.
feedback.Material form: Excluded — Exists conceptually and visually, not materially.
feedback.Passive: Excluded — This trait is not meaningfully applicable to an abstract entity.
feedback.Purposeful / intentional: Included — It was created for the specific purpose of organizing narrative progression.
feedback.Emits output / produces effect: Excluded — It does not generate any intrinsic output.
feedback.Processes or regulates logic/signals: Excluded — Not a logical processor, only a representational frame.
feedback.Transforms or modifies internal state: Excluded — Has no internal state or reactive function.
feedback.Interacts with humans directly: Included — Designed to be read, interpreted, and manipulated by humans.
feedback.Part of a larger system: Excluded — It may be used in systems (e.g., education), but is not structurally embedded.
feedback.System-critical: Excluded — Not essential to any system’s operation.
feedback.Symbolic / representational: Included — Uses symbols and structure to represent a non-physical concept (narrative tension).
feedback.Communicative: Included — Communicates progression, climax, and resolution.
feedback.Logical / rule-based: Included — Follows a narrative logic (e.g., rising action precedes climax).
feedback.Hierarchical / modular: Included — Typically has nested structures like acts or beats.
feedback.Behavior-guiding: Included — Guides writers’ and analysts’ choices in structuring stories.
feedback.Self-referential / meta-conceptual: Excluded — It represents story structure but does not reflect on itself.
feedback.Temporal: Excluded — Represents temporal progression, but is not itself temporal.
feedback.Contextual abstraction: Included — Its meaning depends on the genre, medium, or narrative model.
feedback.Socially / culturally constructed: Included — Varies across cultures and eras; not a universal form.
feedback.Defined by a group/system: Included — Taught and maintained by literary communities.
feedback.Linked to identity or role: Excluded — Not tied to personal or social identity.
feedback.Teachable / transmissible: Included — Taught in creative writing, media studies, and storytelling.
feedback.Visible: Included — Exists specifically as a visual schema.
feedback.Context-sensitive: Included — Interpretation shifts with genre or story type.
feedback.Widely known: Included — Freytag’s Pyramid, Hero’s Journey, etc. are broadly familiar.

encoding_notes: This encoding captures the Story Arc Diagram as a perceptual, symbolic structure that organizes narrative logic. It is not an active functional entity but rather an interpretive and context-shaped tool for human use. It is widely taught, seen, and socially maintained, making its abstract and social layers prominent.
